### convertToDouble() {#a37733c4c22afc6a48194783dbd25487c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="double llvm::APFloat::convertToDouble () const">
Converts this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a> to host double value.

<SectionUser title="Precondition">
The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a> must be built using semantics, that can be represented by the host double type without loss of precision. It can be IEEEdouble and shorter semantics, like IEEEsingle and others.
</SectionUser>

<SectionUser title="Precondition">
The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a> must be built using semantics, that can be represented by the host float type without loss of precision. </SectionUser>

### isExactlyValue() {#a43efe9700a64d52fdf51d350923eef33}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::APFloat::isExactlyValue (double V) const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
We don&#39;t rely on operator== working on double values, as it returns true for things that are clearly not equal, like -0.0 and 0.0.

As such, this method can be used to do an exact bit-for-bit comparison of two floating point values.

We leave the version with the double argument here because it&#39;s just so convenient to write &quot;2.0&quot; and the like. Without this function we&#39;d have to duplicate its logic everywhere it&#39;s called.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apfloat-h/#l01429">1429</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apfloat-h">APFloat.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
